ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Developed an understanding of ancient Greek and Roman perspectives toward and modes of interacting with nature.
How to read Roman and Greek sources and relate them to nature and to current events.

In this class I learned a lot about how the study of ancient texts through the specific lens of the environment and agriculture. I was able to deeply engage with the material and relate it back to modern life. In addition to discussing individual practices and facts with my professor and peers, I was able to learn methods of study from them and feel far more equipped to study antiquity after the class. This class nicely blended modern issues with the study of history and placed issues in conversation that I typically wouldn't think to.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is a bit strange in that it is cross-listed in such different disciplines, and at times leans very heavily in one direction or another. But there is flexibility within some of the optional readings, paper topics, and "foraging" on your own, so you can focus on topics that interest you.

Strengths: Great discussions, interesting topics, interesting readings
Weaknesses: Not sure whether the secondary sources were necessary to read, late discussion board and video provocation uploads

This course was very intentionally crafted and that was visible in the texts selected and the organization of lessons. Encouraging students to bring examples or relevant observations from their own lives created an environment of creative comparison and active engagement. Certain themes were touched on throughout various topics, creating an interesting continual conversation around them. I think a way the course could improve would be through a little more discussion of the historical context. In many cases we did do this, but sometimes we dove directly into the texts without laying the groundwork first. As a non-major, this made it occasionally hard to follow, but was not generally a large issue.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, in general it succeeded. But please please please can we be out of this pandemic next term
Discussion Boards were great in terms of the comments, but they were often uploaded late. The video provocations for also thought-provoking, but they were also uploaded late.

I think that this class adapted well to virtual learning- bringing in all sorts of mediums and topics through the inclusion of "found items" and the discussion posts. The conversation was fairly natural and students were clearly engaged with the material. I think including two virtual lectures, two seminar discussions, and two conversation posts per week could be a little much in addition to the readings and workloads from other classes. That being said, I really did enjoy learning about the material covered in class and the provocations, as well as reading my peer's thoughts in the forums.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are interested in the course material. Because it straddles history, classics, and environmental studies, you'll get a cool mix of information and will learn something regardless of previous knowledge.
Yes, if they are interested in Greek and Roman antiquity!

I would certainly recommend it, if they were the type of person who I thought would enjoy it. While it was exciting to me, by nature of the material and limitations of the subject it might not be the best introductory course to antiquity. However, if someone happened to enjoy the niche intersection of the two subjects (as I most certainly did) I would strongly encourage them to take this class.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone with a background in classics! It was hard to understand the discussion/readings sometimes as a non-classics major, and I think the class would have been more insightful with a good deal of background like most of the students had. However, it was a super fun class and we got to talk about subjects I simply never would have treated otherwise, like ancient food, cooking, alcohol culture, farming, etc.!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: virtual seminar with some recorded "provocation" videos from Prof. Freudenburg
We met virtually twice a week, as well as having two recorded lectures, and asynchronous online discussion posts throughout the week.
